Tel.: +82 522592706. Graphical abstract Photocatalysis has been attracting much research interest because of its wide applications in renewable energy and environmental remediation. There are many materials that are found to show good photocatalytic activity in the presence of ultraviolet (UV) and visible light. However, the applications of these materials are limited to the UV portion of sunlight. α-Fe2O3 has an advantage over the other conventional materials like TiO2, ZnO, etc. in using solar energy for photocatalytic applications due to its lower band gap ∼2.2eV value. As a result of which Fe2O3 is capable of absorbing a large portion of the visible solar spectrum (absorbance edge ∼600nm). Also its good chemical stability in aqueous medium, low cost, abundance and nontoxic nature makes it a promising material for photocatalytic water treatment and water splitting applications. Except these advantages the usage of Fe2O3 has been restricted by many anomalies such as higher e–h recombination effect, low diffusion length and VB positioning (VB is positive with respect to H+/H2 potential). This article reviews the research that has been carried out to overcome these basic limitations and to enhance the photocatalytic activity of α-Fe2O3. Keywords Fe2O3 Thin film Photocatalytic activity Water splitting Dye degradation 1 Introduction The sun is the principal energy source for earth and sustains life on earth. The most important natural method for utilization of solar energy is the photosynthesis process by plants to produce carbohydrates and oxygen gas (O2) by utilizing carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O). Most of our day-to-day energy requirements are being met by fossil fuels. However, the limited availability of these non-renewable sources of energy has motivated researchers to find different techniques to use solar energy as an alternative for future energy needs. The most common method to directly convert solar energy into electric energy is photovoltaic (PV), and this process utilizes semiconductors which generate electron–hole pairs upon illumination with visible light, thereby producing electric power in solar cells. However, the utility of photovoltaic cells is limited by poor conversion efficiency. To overcome these problems, researchers have tried to find suitable methods to produce hydrogen (H2) from photocatalysis of H2O using sunlight, which can be used in fuel cells for power generation. Another important current problem before scientists is environmental pollution, such as water contamination, from industrial hazardous waste. Common pollutants include toxic organic compounds like chlorinated and non-chlorinated aliphatic and aromatic compounds, organic dyes, surfactants, detergents, insecticides, pesticides, herbicides, disinfection byproducts, volatile organic compounds, plastics, heavy metals, NO x , SO x , CO, NH3, and pathogens (bacteria, fungi and viruses) [1]. Although there are many methods that have been followed to remove such wastes from water, none are able to fully purify the water. Further, the processes are very slow, and need high temperature along with strict pH control. These problems are overcome by the advanced oxidation process (AOP), which involves the production of highly reactive species (OH−, O2 −, O3) generated by a light source [2]. These species react with contaminants and form simple, non-hazardous byproducts. Photocatalytic ability in materials is one of the most interesting research topics due to its usefulness in various fields such as H2 generation [3–5], artificial photosynthesis [6,7], waste water treatment [8–10], removal of toxic gases from air [11–13] and dye sensitized solar cells (DSSC) [14,15]. 1.1 What is photocatalytic activity A catalyst is a material whose presence enhances the rate of a chemical reaction but itself remains unchanged at the end of the reaction. Some common examples of catalysts are ammonia formation in the presence of iron, hydrogenation of CC bonds in the presence of nickel, enzymes for biological reactions, and many more. Photocatalytic activity refers to the catalytic properties of materials in the presence of light, and photocatalysis is the acceleration of the rate of a chemical reaction by activating a catalyst by ultraviolet (UV) or visible light. The catalysts in photocatalytic reactions are normally semiconductor materials, which can form electrons and holes when exposed to light, and the reactions are normally either oxidation or reduction. Photocatalysts are generally divided into two categories (i) homogeneous catalysts and (ii) heterogeneous catalysts. A catalyst is defined as homogeneous if it is present in the same phase as that of the reagents, which means that the catalysts are present as solutes in a homogeneous catalytic reaction system. In contrast, a catalyst is said to be heterogeneous if it is present in a different phase than the reaction mixture. The advantages of heterogeneous catalysts are that they can be easily separated from the reaction mixture and can be reused [16]. An ideal photocatalyst should have the following properties: (i) it should have good photoactivity, (ii) it must be biologically and chemically inert, (iii) it must be suitable for absorbing visible or near UV light, (iv) it also must be stable to photocorrosion, (v) cheap, and (vi) non-toxic [17]. The steps of a photocatalytic reaction involve the absorption of light by a semiconductor material followed by an electron transfer from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) creating a hole in the VB. The VB and CB are separated by some energy barrier called the band gap (E g). Typical band gaps of some semiconductors are listed in Table 1 . The interface transfer process, which involves electrons and holes and their deactivation by recombination, determines the efficiency of the photocatalyst. The detailed process regarding photocatalytic mechanism can be obtained from [2,18]. The hydroperoxyl radical, if formed, also serves as a scavenger, thus doubly prolonging the lifetime of photo-holes. Both the oxidation and reduction can take place at the surface of the photoexcited semiconductor photocatalyst. Recombination between electrons and hole occurs unless oxygen is available to scavenge the electrons to form superoxides (O2 −), followed by its protonated form, the hydroperoxyl radical (HO2 ), and subsequently to hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Each subsequent ion formed reacts to form intermediates and final products. As a consequence of this series of reactions, the photonic excitation of the catalyst serves as the initial step of the activation of the whole catalytic system. Solar water splitting is another important application of photocatalysis. The electrons and holes generated by the excitation of semiconductors simultaneously initiate oxidation/reduction reactions, which is similar to that of electrolysis. The photo-generated e− moves toward the cathode by application of external potential and reduce H+ ions to H2. However the photogenerated h+ moves toward the anode to oxidize the H2O molecules to form O2. The reactions are as follows. Cathode: H2O+2h+ =1/2O2 +2H+ Anode: 2H+ +2e− =H2 The electrons and holes react with water molecules to form H2 and O2, respectively. The potential involves in a water splitting reaction is 1.23eV, which concludes a photocatalyst that can be considered for water splitting applications should have a band gap value greater than 1.23eV and also suitable positioning of the CB and VB levels. The bottom level of the conduction band of the semiconductor has to be more negative than the redox potential of H+/H2 (0V vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE)), whereas the valence band of the semiconductor has to be more positive than the redox potential of O2/H2O (1.23V) [19]. The positioning of the VB and CB depends on the d-orbital distribution of a particular semiconductor. In TiO2 the VB is more negative in comparison to the H+/H2 potential making it a suitable material for H2 production. Although the band gap of Fe2O3 suggests utilization of larger range of solar spectrum, the application is limited by the VB position of Fe2O3 which is more positive in comparison to the H+/H2 electrode making it unsuitable for H2 production. Several other semiconductors who have negative VB in reference to the H2 electrode are suitable for usage because of their instability in aqueous medium. Several attempts have been made to shift the VB of Fe2O3 to the more negative position of VB of H2 potential. The efficiency of photon to H2 conversion has been described by several terms such as Quantum Efficiency (QE) and Applied Bias Photon-to-Current Efficiency (ABPE). The details regarding the water splitting mechanisms and efficiency can be read from the review articles by Liao et al. [20] and Walter et al. [21]. The photocatalytic properties and efficiencies are influenced by the surface structures of the photocatalysts including surface area, porosity, defects, nature of the exposed planes, concentration of pollutants, amount of dye, pH of the reaction medium, calcination temperature, reaction temperature, light intensity, and presence of oxidizing agents [22]. There are many techniques that have been followed to enhance the photocatalytic activity of a material such as surface modification, doping with other materials, formation of composites, and formation of heterostructures (Fig. 2 ). 1.2 Applications of photocatalysis The photocatalytic activity of materials can utilize solar energy, which makes this an important alternative to present energy sources. Further, photocatalysts can be used for environmental remediation, which involves the degradation of organic and inorganic pollutants present in water as well as in air. Further, applications have been found in disinfecting water by reduction of microorganisms in water. Self-cleaning applications of photocatalytic materials can be used in exterior tiles, kitchen, and bathroom components, interior furnishings, plastic surfaces, aluminum siding, building stone, and curtains and window blinds. Photocatalytic activity can be used for H2 production, which can further be used in fuel cells. The possibility of reducing CO2 using sunlight in a similar manner to that occurring in plants, better known as artificial photosynthesis, is another important application of photocatalysis. 2 Fe2O3 (iron oxide) 2.1 Structure and properties Iron oxide is a transition metal oxide which has different stoichiometric and crystalline structures, including wüstite (FeO), hematite (α-Fe2O3), maghemite (ν-Fe2O3), and magnetite (Fe3O4). Out of all the phases, hematite (α-Fe2O3) is the most stable state of iron oxide at ambient conditions. The structure of α-Fe2O3 is a hexagonal crystal system consisting of iron atoms surrounded by six oxygen atoms. Hematite's strong absorption of yellow to UV photons in the visible region and transmission of orange to infrared photons gives it a characteristic red color. However, it has fairly uniform reflectivity as a function of visible light wavelength gives specular hematite a metallic appearance. In hematite, the iron and oxygen atoms are arranged in a corundum structure, which is a trigonal-hexagonal scalenohedral with space group R-3c, lattice parameters a =5.0356nm, c =13.7489nm, and six formula units per unit cell. In α-Fe2O3, the oxide ions (O2−) are arranged along the (001) plane of a hexagonal closed-packed lattice, whereas two-thirds of the octahedral interstices are occupied by the cations (Fe3+) in the (001) basal planes. The tetrahedral sites are unoccupied. This cationic arrangement generates pairs of FeO6 octahedrons, in which the edges are shared by three neighboring octahedrons in the same plane and one face with an octahedron in an adjacent plane in the (001) direction. The hematite exhibits C3v symmetry (Fig. 3 ) [23], and there are two different FeO bond lengths [24]. Hematite is antiferromagnetic at temperatures below 260K and is a weak (parasitic) ferromagnet at room temperature. While the magnetic properties of hematite are not particularly dependent on its photo electrochemical performance, the iron spin configuration does influence the optoelectronic and carrier transport properties of hematite. The absorption of photons by hematite begins in the near-infrared spectral region where weak absorption bands (with absorption coefficients, a, of the order 103 cm−1) are due to transition states electron between two d orbital energy levels of the Fe3+ ion, which are split by an intrinsic crystal field [25]. Analysis by means of a Tauc plot shows the indirect nature of the band gap for the α-Fe2O3 involving d orbital to d orbital transitions and a direct transition from O (2p) to Fe (3d), which occurs only for band gaps >3.2eV [26–28]. Hematite (α-Fe2O3), an environmentally friendly n-type semiconductor (E g =2.1eV), has been widely used in many fields such as lithium-ion batteries [29], gas sensors [30–32], photocatalysis [33,34], water treatment [35] and water splitting for generating H2. 2.2 Photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 There are many semiconductor oxides, sulfides, and nitrides that show photocatalytic activity. However, most oxides have an absorption edge only in the UV region which limits the usage of most of the solar spectrum. Although sulfides and nitrides have a lower band gap, the stability of these materials in an aqueous medium is a major disadvantage. Hematite, or α-Fe2O3, is one promising candidate for photocatalytic applications due to its narrow band gap of about 2.0–2.2eV. Further, hematite absorbs light up to 600nm, collects up to 40% of the solar spectrum energy, is stable in most aqueous solutions (pH>3), and is one of the cheapest semiconductor materials available. Due to the band gap value α-Fe2O3 (2.1eV) and the fact that its VB edge is substantially lower than the water oxidation potential, it is a promising photoanode material for photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting. Photochemical water splitting involves a dispersed material in pure water and accordingly produces hydrogen and oxygen homogeneously throughout the solution [36]. The theoretical photocurrent density of α-Fe2O3 is ∼12.6mA/cm2 under AM 1.5 G solar irradiation, and the solar energy conversion efficiency is ∼15.5% in an ideal tandem PEC cell [37,38]. However, the photocatalytic performance of α-Fe2O3 is limited by certain factors such as high recombination rate of electrons and holes, low diffusion lengths of holes (2–4nm), and poor conductivity, which led to both low efficiencies and a larger requisite over potential for photo-assisted water oxidation [39–43]. Many attempts have been made by researchers to overcome these anomalies of α-Fe2O3 such as lowering the recombination rate by forming nanostructures, enhancement in conductivity by doping with suitable metals and improving the charge transfer ability [44,45]. Apart from water-splitting applications, the photocatalytic activity of hematite can be used for elimination of organic compounds in water treatment applications. The mechanism of the degradation of Congo red dye (CR) was explained by Sundaramurthy et al. [46]. Specifically, photosensitization of the CR dye first takes place where charge transfer occurs from the LUMO level of the dye to the conduction band of the photocatalyst. This is followed by the semiconductor-initiated photocatalytic reaction where α-Fe2O3 generates an electron and a hole pair upon photoirradiation. The electron ejects from the valence band of α-Fe2O3 to the conduction band, leaving behind a hole in the valence band (Eq. (3)). The photogenerated electron of α-Fe2O3 generates intermediate superoxide radicals (O2 −) by reacting with chemisorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface and oxygen in the aqueous solution (Eq. (5)). The superoxide radicals (O2 −) along with dissociated water (H+) form hydroperoxyl radicals (HO2) (Eq. (6)) and H2O2 is formed from the hydroperoxyl radicals (Eq. (7)). The hydroxyl radicals (OH−) are formed on the surface of the catalyst by the reaction with photo generated holes (h+) with adsorbed water (OH2) (Eqs. (4) and (8)). These reactive radicals and intermediate species react with CR dye, and degrade it into non-toxic organic compounds. (1) CR+hν→CR (2) CR +α-Fe2O3 →CR + +α-Fe2O3 (eCB −) (3) α-Fe2O3 +hν→α-Fe2O3 (eCB − +hVB +) (4) H2O→H+ +OH− (5) eCB − +O2 →O2 − (6) O2 − +H+ aq →HO2 (7) HO2 +HO2 ↔H2O2 +O2 (8) hVB + +OH− aq →OH − (9) CR/CR + +(O2 −, HO2 , H2O2, OH −)→Degradation Products… In an additional application, α-Fe2O3 is also a good photocatalyst for aniline to azobenzene [47] and acrylamide polymerization [48]. The mechanism of acrylamide formation is a photopolymerization reaction, which starts with the formation of holes in the valence band of α-Fe2O3 molecules followed by the formation of acrylamide radicals. The step is followed by the subsequent recombination of the growing macro-radicals. 3 Research on the photocatalytic property of α-Fe2O3 Having discussed some of the applications of hematite catalysts above, we focus here on three forms of hematite that have been studied. Work associated with hematite powders is addressed first, followed by studies related to modified and doped hematite. This section concludes with a discussion on thin solid hematite films. 3.1 α-Fe2O3 powder As the surface area plays an important role in determining the photocatalytic activity of materials, researchers have attempted to reduce the size of photocatalytic materials and enhance the photocatalytic properties of these materials by producing hematite in a nanoscale powder form. Many methods have been followed to synthesize Fe2O3 in nanocrystalline form and in different shapes including hydrolysis [49], co-precipitation [50,51], hydrothermal methods [52–54], solvothermal methods [55,56], ionic liquid assisted synthesis [57], thermal decomposition [58], combustion methods [59], and a combination reflex condensation and hydrothermal method [60] (Table 2 ). Hosseinian et al. [61] synthesized nanostructured iron oxide of different morphologies and different phase compositions (α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4) by a solid-state reaction route. The photocatalytic activity was checked with respect to degradation of CR, and it was observed that the samples containing a mixture of α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 showed better photocatalytic activity than that of the pure α-Fe2O3. The higher photocatalytic activity observed for a mixed phase sample was attributed to the higher transfer of electrons and holes generated during the photoreaction of α-Fe2O3 to the valence band of Fe3O4, which limits the recombination rates [62]. Yang et al. [63] synthesized α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles of uniform size (170nm to 2μm) by a hydrothermal route to study both magnetic as well as photocatalytic properties. The α-Fe2O3 powders with the smaller crystallite sizes show the highest photocatalytic degradation efficiency than that of the powders with larger crystallite sizes. Further, all the samples showed higher efficiency for degradation of the dye than that of the commercially available Degussa P25. Nano structured α-Fe2O3 powders of 25–55nm in size Apte et al. [59] synthesized and their photocatalytic activity was analyzed with respect to decomposition of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) gas. α-Fe2O3 (necked structures) showed good photocatalytic properties and production of H2. Zhou et al. [64] synthesized nanorods of α-Fe2O3 by thermal dehydration and compared the photocatalytic activity with microrods. The authors reported a higher degradation rate for Rhodamine B (RhB) for nanodimensional α-Fe2O3 than that of the corresponding micron-size rods. Higher FeO bond stretching frequencies were proposed as one of the key factors behind the enhanced photocatalytic activity. Particle size, composition, porosity, and the local structures are also the key factors that affect the photocatalytic properties of materials. Townsend et al. [49] compared the photocatalytic activity of three forms of Fe2O3 including bulk (crystallite size 120nm), ultrasonicated bulk (crystallite size 40nm), and nanopowders of α-Fe2O3 (crystallite size 5.4nm). They found that the rate of oxygen evolution is higher when the crystallite size becomes smaller, and the highest rate was reported for α-Fe2O3 nanopowders (1072μmol/hg). In the case of α-Fe2O3 nanopowders, the hole diffusion length is comparable to the crystallite size, which results in more availability of holes to react with water. Dang et al. [50] reported the effects of calcination temperature, reaction temperature, amount of catalyst, and duration of reaction on the catalytic properties. They reported an increase in photocatalytic activity with increasing calcination temperature, reaction temperature, and catalytic amount up to a certain extent, after which the activity decreases. Similar effects were also reported by Pawar et al. [65] for α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles synthesized by a sol-gel technique followed by heat treatment at different calcination temperatures. The efficiency of the catalyst was analyzed with respect to various experimental variables such as calcination temperature, pH, light intensity, and concentration of dye and catalyst. Samples calcined at 600°C show the highest photocatalytic activity because of the formation of the more dominant α-Fe2O3 phase. The photocatalytic properties were analyzed for the 3–10 pH range, and the reactions at higher pH conditions showed better photocatalytic properties. In basic pH conditions, formation of OH radical is more favored and electrostatic abstractive effects between cationic malachite green dye and negatively charged surface of α-Fe2O3 increases, which results in a higher probability of dye degradation. Light intensity shows a linear effect on the photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 due to the increased availability of photons for reaction. Similar effects were also reported by Liu et al. [66] for α-Fe2O3 nanorods. These authors examined the effect of the amount of catalyst and initial dye concentration on the photocatalytic properties. The optimum catalyst amount was reported to be 50mg/L to achieve the highest photocatalytic activity. However, the photocatalytic activity degrades with increasing dye concentration. This effect was justified in terms of a decrease in transparency with an increase in dye and catalyst concentration after a particular value. In a photoreaction, the porosity of the catalyst plays a major role in enhancing the photocatalytic properties. Sundarmurthy et al. [46] synthesized 1D α-Fe2O3 nanobraids and nanoporous structures by electrospinning to analyze the photocatalytic properties. The nanostructures show superior photocatalytic activity for degradation of CR in a small fraction of time due to the porous surface and nano-sized crystallites of α-Fe2O3, which provide more active catalytic centers and allow effective interaction between organic dye and α-Fe2O3, thereby enhancing photocatalytic degradation performance. α-Fe2O3 porous structures were prepared by Zhang et al. [52] and the photocatalytic activity was analyzed by the degradation of methylene blue (MB). They analyzed the effect of porosity and the amount of catalyst on photocatalytic activity. It has been reported that an optimized amount of catalyst (20mg) is required for getting the highest rate of degradation of MB, less or more than this amount leads to lower photocatalytic activity. Large amounts of catalyst result in lesser illumination, and when the amount of catalyst is insufficient, the number of active sites is not sufficient to degrade the organic dye. Geng et al. [67] followed a Ni2+/surfactant system route for synthesizing α-Fe2O3 with a porous structure and rough surface which shows better photocatalytic properties than that of the α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the degradation of MB as a result of higher surface area. Gang et al. [34] prepared α-Fe2O3 micro/nano spheres synthesized by hydrothermal synthesis followed by thermal treatment. The micro/nano spheres show better dye degradation efficiency than that of the nanopowders. The calculated reaction rate for spherical structures is more than twice than that of the reaction rate of nanopowders and 12 times the reaction rate of the micron-size powders. The better photocatalytic activity is the result of the higher specific surface area and porous structure. Xu et al. [68], Zhou et al. [69] and Bharathi et al. [60] reported an effect of the surface morphology of α-Fe2O3 on its photocatalytic activity. α-Fe2O3 nanostructures with different morphologies such as microflowers, nanospindles, nanoparticles and nanorhombohedra were synthesized. And the photocatalytic activity was analyzed by monitoring the degradation of RhB in the presence of the catalyst. The best photocatalytic activity was observed for the samples with highest surface area and porosity. Similar surface area effects were also reported by Cheng et al. [70] for flower-like α-Fe2O3 nanostructures synthesized by a biphasic interfacial reaction route. The photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 were evaluated by measuring the degradation of RhB. The results were compared with the commercial α-Fe2O3 powders and nanoflowers were found to have better photocatalytic property than the commercial powders. The enhancement was related to the increase in crystallinity and increase in surface area, which is also supported by results of other authors for TiO2 [71] and Fe2O3 [72]. Similar surface area effects were also reported by Cao et al. [73], Xu et al. [56], and Li et al. [53] for α-Fe2O3 hollow microspheres prepared by solvothermal and hydrothermal methods. The photocatalytic activity was analyzed by degradation of salicylic acid. The hollow spheres associated with nanosheets show better photocatalytic activity than that of the nanoparticles of α-Fe2O3. Similar results were also reported by Maji et al. [58], where α-Fe2O3 powders prepared at 500°C show better photocatalytic activity for degradation of rose Bengal dye than that of the powders prepared at 600°C and commercially available TiO2 (Degussa-25) as a result of higher surface area. α-Fe2O3 hollow spindles and spheres were prepared by Li et al. [54] and Xu et al. [57], respectively. These authors reported an enhancement in photocatalytic degradation efficiency as a result of the enhancement in specific surface area, which results in more unsaturated surface coordination sites exposed to the solution. The hollow microsphere facilitates more electron-hole transport and lowers the recombination rate. Hollow microspheres allow multiple reflections of visible light within the interior that encourage a more efficient use of the light source and enhance light-harvesting, leading to an increased quantity of OH available to participate in the photocatalytic reaction. Along with this, the hollow spheres also provide ideal channels for the dye molecules and increase the probability of interaction. Apart from crystallite size, the orientation of crystallites also plays a major role in enhancing the photocatalytic properties. This effect has been reported by Wu et al. [74], in which the authors prepared α-Fe2O3 nanocubes by a solvothermal method and reported a higher photocatalytic property for the (104) planes than that of the samples with (012) planes. The photocatalytic properties involve Fenton's reaction. The amount of Fe3+ on the surfaces of the catalyst play a very important role in the Fenton reaction in which the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ generates hydroxyl radicals (OH) [75]. It has been reported by Lv et al. [76] that (104) planes of α-Fe2O3 contain 10.3 atoms/nm2 of exposed Fe3+ ions, whereas the (012) planes contain 7.33 atoms/nm2 of exposed Fe3+ ions. This explains the higher reactivity of (104) planes than that of the (012) planes. Along with the surface morphology, oxygen pressure and amount of the catalyst also play a major role in enhancing the photocatalytic properties. Isaev et al. [77] reported an enhancement in photocatalytic activity with an increase in quantity of Fe2O3 up to certain point, after that, the photocatalytic activity is decreased. Similarly, the authors reported an enhancement in dye degradation with increased oxygen content. The reason behind the enhancement in photocatalytic behavior is due to the formation of more oxygen containing active species such as HO, O2 , and HO2 oxidizing species. 3.2 Modified/doped Fe2O3 The previous section includes a review of attempts made to enhance the photocatalytic activity of pure α-Fe2O3 in nanocrystalline and other morphological forms. Further, studies that included the effects of morphology, size, pH, temperature, and annealing temperature on the photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 were discussed. This section will provide a literature review on the effect of doping and surface modification of α-Fe2O3 on its photocatalytic properties. Modification of the structure and doping is a common practice by scientists for enhancing the photocatalytic properties. Similar attempts have been carried out for TiO2, ZnO, and WO3. Fe2O3 has been doped with Al [78], ZnO, Ti, WO3 [79], and Ga [80] to improve its photocatalytic activity (Table 2). Zhao et al. [81] synthesized yeast cell/α-Fe2O3 nanocrystals to observe the photocatalytic effect in the degradation of methyl orange. The effect of yeast cells and sintering temperature on the photocatalytic properties was observed. The amount of yeast cells affects the specific surface area of the sample, which, in turn, changes the photocatalytic activity. The hybrid α-Fe2O3 (yeast cell amount is 0.6g) samples dried at 80°C and calcined at 300°C exhibit high surface area and high photocatalytic activity. Li et al. [78] doped α-Fe2O3 with different aluminum (Al) content to analyze the effect of aluminum content on photocatalytic stability. The authors reported a strong effect of Al on the specific surface area and pore size distribution with increasing Al content. Degradation of bisphenol-A was monitored to determine the effect of Al doping on photocatalytic activity. The crystallinity, crystal structure and the properties of the surface structure were reasons for the improvement in photocatalytic activity. Variation in both Al content and mixed crystal structure showed better photocatalytic activity than variation in only one or the other variables. Although the band gap value of hematite and magnetite are the same, the positions of the CB and VB band are different, which helps in transfer of electrons from the conduction or valence band of one to the other to reduce the recombination effect. This is the reason behind the enhancement in the photocatalytic effect. Doping of α-Fe2O3 with noble metals such as platinum (Pt) and gold (Au) has been carried out by Chen et al. [82] and Cao et al. [83], respectively. Pt/α-Fe2O3 catalysts that were prepared by Long et al. were analyzed with respect to the degradation of MB. The average size of the Pt nanoparticles embedded in the α-Fe2O3 matrix is 3.9nm, and is observed to be at the defective positions. It was observed that the photocatalytic activity increases with increases in surface Pt atoms because of higher charge separation. Pradhan et al. [84] also synthesized α-Fe2O3 of different shapes and Pt-doped α-Fe2O3 nanocrystals. These authors reported an enhancement in photocatalytic activity by doping with Pt metal for degradation of different dyes in comparison to the undoped catalysts. The effect of Pt doping in α-Fe2O3 on photocatalytic dechlorination of 2,6-dichloroindophenol was analyzed by Baumanis et al. [85]. The 5wt% Pt/α-Fe2O3 was found to show the best photocatalytic performance. Further, these authors varied the Pt concentration from 1 to 5wt%, and similar studies were also done for Au doping with α-Fe2O3 by Cao et al. [83]. The sizes of gold particles were varied from 2 to 20nm to see the effect of the size of Au particles on the photocatalytic activity. Experiments were carried out to observe the degradation rate of RhB. The kinetic rate constant of the Au/α-Fe2O3 catalyst increases with a decrease in Au particle sizes. The high catalytic activity may be attributed to highly dispersed α-Fe2O3 nanocrystals with well-distributed small Au nanoparticles on their surfaces, allowing effective interactions between the reactants and metal catalysts. Another reason for the higher photocatalytic activity of the metal-doped α-Fe2O3 is the presence of the metal nanostructures, which act like optical antenna to concentrate the light energy at the near surface. Therefore, the α-Fe2O3 nanocrystals near the Au/α-Fe2O3 interfaces would encounter a much more intense band gap excitation by this surface plasmon enhanced electric field, which can generate more photoexcited electrons for the photocatalytic reaction. Pradhan et al. [86] analyzed the photocatalytic effect of Zn and Fe as well as Ce and Fe mixed oxides [87] and found that a 50:50, Fe:Zn as well as Ce:Fe ratio shows the best photocatalytic properties. Mixed oxide catalysts of different Fe and Zn ratios were prepared by a solution combustion method. The photocatalytic properties were analyzed with respect to the degradation of chloronitrophenol (CNP) and Rhodamine 6G and generation H2. The mixed oxides show better properties than those of both ZnO and α-Fe2O3. The higher photocatalytic activity was a consequence of the higher specific surface area and lowered recombination rate of the 50:50 mixed oxide sample. The suggested mechanisms are shown in Fig. 4 . The photocatalytic activity of Fe/Ce mixed oxide samples were analyzed with respect to degradation of phenol, MB dye and CR dye. The higher photocatalytic activity of the 1:1 Ce:Fe samples the result of the high surface area and surface activity. Many attempts have been made by many researchers to dope α-Fe2O3 with anionic materials such as fluorine (F) and nitrogen (N) [88] for enhancing the photocatalytic activity. Doping with anionic materials introduces an additional acceptor level, which leads to enhancement in charge separation and lowers the recombination effect, thereby increasing the photocatalytic effect. Pure α-Fe2O3 has only band alignment near the oxygen production levels, whereas, when doped with N, the band alignments approach the H2 production level, so N-doped α-Fe2O3 can be used for production of H2 also. S and N co doped Fe2O3 has been synthesized by Co-precipitation method by Pradhan et al. [89]. Comparative studies have been carried out for different degradation process such as adsorption, photo-Fenton, Fenton, and photocatalytic degradation of RhB. A maximum 95% degradation of the dye was observed under natural sunlight. α-Fe2O3 has also been doped by different carbon materials such as carbon quantum dots (CQD) to enhance the charge separation and photocatalytic activity because of the large electron storage capacity of carbon nanostructures. As a result, the electrons produced by the photoexcitation of α-Fe2O3 can move freely in the carbon network. Byong et al. [90] prepared carbon quantum dot (CQD)-doped α-Fe2O3 by a solvent-thermal process and analyzed the photocatalytic properties with respect to MB degradation. Activity was found to be enhanced in comparison to the pure α-Fe2O3. Insertion of CQDs in the α-Fe2O3 matrix enhanced the specific surface area and reduced the pore size, which, in turn, increased the probability of interaction between the dye molecules and the catalyst. Also, the insertion of CQDs enhanced the fast electron transfer between the catalyst and conducting network of CQDs, which inhibits the recombination rate. A similar analysis was also carried out by Zhang et al. [91] for degradation of toxic gases such as gas phase benzene and methanol. Along with this, the π–π interactions between the CQDs and benzene structures are also beneficial for the transport of electrons and enhances the reaction rate. CQDs are capable of absorbing longer wavelength light and emitting shorter wavelength light, as a result of their upconversion photoluminescence property, which, in turn, excites α-Fe2O3 to form electron–hole pairs (Fig. 5 ). Apart from CQDs, another form of carbon that has been embedded into α-Fe2O3 is graphene oxide (GO) [92–94]. Hong et al. [92] and Sheng et al. [95] prepared a α-Fe2O3/GO composite to enhance the photocatalytic activity of α-Fe2O3. Hong et al. analyzed the photocatalytic properties with respect to the degradation of an organic pollutant (toluene). The specific surface areas of the composite samples were quite higher than that of the α-Fe2O3 powders, which enhances the toluene degradation more for the composite catalysts than that of bare α-Fe2O3 powders. The reusability of the composites were analyzed by repeating the reaction for 4 cycles, and this result showed that the degradation of toluene was ∼71% after the fourth cycle, which means the α-Fe2O3/GO catalyst has good stability and reusability. However, Sheng et al. [95] analyzed the photocatalytic degradation efficiency of effect GO/α-Fe2O3 with respect to degradation of RhB and 4-nitrophenol. The authors reported that the GO/α-Fe2O3 composites show ∼90% degradation of organic dye in the pH range of 2–10, which overcomes the narrow pH range of Fenton's photoreaction, which is attributed to the electronegativity of the GO surface. An increase in the amount of catalyst and H2O2 enhances the photocatalytic activity of the GO/α-Fe2O3 as a result of the more active sites and oxidizing atmosphere, respectively. Another attempt to improve the photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 was also made by Pradhan et al. [94] by making a composite of α-Fe2O3 with reduced graphene oxide (RGO). The catalysts were synthesized by a hydrothermal route, and the performance of photocatalytic activity was discussed with respect to the specific surface area, interaction between nanorods and graphene nanosheets, synergism between α-Fe2O3 nanorods and RGO sheets, effective utilization of light by the composites, photoluminescence spectra, measurement of the photocurrent, and formation of hydroxyl radicals. The composition of RGO was varied from 0–7%, and the photocatalytic activity was measured with respect to phenol degradation. The highest phenol degradation was observed for the 5wt% RGO/α-Fe2O3 composites (∼70%), and this was the result of the highest specific area achieved per wt% of the composite sample. Further, photogenerated electrons were easily channelized in the RGO sheet due to the sp2 hybridization of the RGO sheets. This decreased the recombination effect, which is a major cause for the lower photocatalytic activity of α-Fe2O3. Another attempt was made by Huang et al. [95] to improve the photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 by making a composite with another structure of carbon (C3N4). The g-C3N4/α-Fe2O3 composites were prepared by a solid-state reaction process and showed high efficiency for the degradation of RhB. The highest photocatalytic activity of the g-C3N4/α-Fe2O3 composite was observed at a g-C3N4 content of 8.6% under visible light irradiation; this value is almost 4.8 times higher than that of the pure α-Fe2O3. The enhancement in visible light photoactivity of g-C3N4/α-Fe2O3 composites was attributed to the introduction of g-C3N4 and the interaction between g-C3N4 and α-Fe2O3. A suitable amount of C3N4 causes well dispersed composites, which enhances e-hole separation, leading to the higher photocatalytic activity. Lumei et al. [94] studied the visible catalytic activity of α-Fe2O3 coupled with N-doped GO (Fig. 6 ). The catalysts were prepared by first doping graphene with N through a one-pot ammonia-modified hydrothermal process followed by coupling with nanocrystalline α-Fe2O3 by a common wet-chemical method with the aim to increase the separation of electrons and holes. It has been reported previously that the photo generated charge separation of α-Fe2O3 is found to be enhanced in N2 or in an air atmosphere after coupling with a certain ratio of graphene. This is particularly obvious for graphene doped with a proper amount of nitrogen. This is responsible for the improved visible photocatalytic activities of α-Fe2O3 for degradation of gas-phase acetaldehyde and liquid-phase phenol after coupling graphene doped with a proper amount of N species. Apart from doping, α-Fe2O3 has also been modified with different functional groups in order to enhance the photocatalytic activity. Limin et al. [97] synthesized a series of Fe2O3/FeOOH nanostructures with different shapes such as spherical, cubic, chained-sphere, and dendritic, to study the effect of surface area and crystal structure on photocatalytic activity with respect to degradation of salicylic acid. It was reported by the authors that the crystalline structures show more photocatalytic activity than the amorphous structures, in contrast to the higher surface area of amorphous structures. In crystalline structures, the degradation of salicylic acid was improved for nanostructures with more specific surface area. Yan et al. [98] synthesized different samples of α-Fe2O3 and silica supported α-Fe2O3 sintered at different temperatures (150–900°C) for improving the photocatalytic activity of hematite with respect to degradation of orange II. Activity was analyzed as a function of concentration of oxidizing species, sintering temperature and pH of the reaction medium. The crystallite size of silica-supported α-Fe2O3 was lower than that of the bare α-Fe2O3. As a result, the specific surface area of silica-supported α-Fe2O3 was higher than that of the bare α-Fe2O3. The crystallite size of both samples increased with increasing sintering temperature. The optimal temperature for the highest rate constant was 400°C. Although the silica supported α-Fe2O3 sample showed better photocatalytic activity than that of the bare α-Fe2O3 over all experimental conditions, recycling experiments showed a lowering of photocatalytic activity for silica-supported α-Fe2O3 relative to the control. This result is explained on the basis of dissolution of ferric species on silica, which forms lower photocatalytically active iron hydroxide. 3.3 Thin films of Fe2O3 Preparation of thin films is another method to reduce the size and change the properties of materials. The main advantages of thin film technology are miniaturization of devices and cost reduction. Fundamental properties of materials are mainly dependent on the microstructure, and it is possible to tune the properties of any material from that of the bulk properties by synthesizing it in nanocrystalline form (either in nanocrystalline powder or in the form of thin films). In addition to the process parameters used in deposition, the microstructure of materials is also dependent on the film thickness [99]. Chen et al. [100] synthesized α-Fe2O3 thin films by RF magnetron sputtering on Si(100) substrates to study the effect of film thickness on photocatalytic activity. The authors reported an increase in photocatalytic activity with increasing in film thickness. Improved photocatalytic activity for higher thickness films was the result of an increase in crystallite size leading to higher surface roughness and lower band gap values. A smaller band gap results in high electron–hole pair formation and higher roughness values provide higher active sites for reactions (Table 3 ). Andrew et al. [101] reported the effect of the substrate on the photochemical properties of α-Fe2O3 thin films deposited on SrTiO3 and alumina substrates. The better photocatalytic for the films deposited on SrTiO3 activity was explained on the basis of the substrate structure, which leads to a lowering of charge recombination and an enhancement in catalytic action. An enhancement in decomposition rate of 2-naphthol by 20% under anodic biased conditions were reported by Tetsuro et al. [102] for Fe2O3 thin films deposited on SnO2-coated glass substrates by a metal organic deposition method. The enhancement in the catalytic process is explained on the basis of a decrease in electron-hole pair recombination rate as a result of the removal of electrons from the α-Fe2O3 surface by the application of an anodic voltage. Tamboli et al. [103] prepared α-Fe2O3 thin films on fluorine-doped SnO2 (FTO)-coated glass plates to analyze the effect of film thickness, post annealing temperature, and duration of annealing on the PEC performance of the α-Fe2O3 films. Increases in annealing temperature showed an enhancement in PEC properties as a result of the increase in crystallinity and decrease in excess voids present in the film. The authors also reported an increase in photocurrent with an increase in film thickness. Similar results were also reported by Rahman et al. [104], who prepared thin films of α-Fe2O3 on a (FTO) substrate by an electrodeposition method to study the effect of post annealing temperature on photoactivity of the films. The authors reported an enhancement in photoactivity with increasing annealing temperature. Films annealed at 820°C showed the highest photocurrent of 0.67mA/cm2. Several explanations have been suggested by these authors, one of which is the inter diffusion of Sn from substrates to films due to high temperature treatment, which increases the electronic conductivity of the film. The other reason that has been suggested by these authors is a decrease in grain boundary area that leads to lowering of the e−–h+ recombination rate. Wei et al. [105] prepared α-Fe2O3 thin films for thermal oxidation of Fe foil at different temperatures and different oxidation conditions to control the morphology of films. They also analyzed the effect of the different morphologies on water splitting capability. Hydrogen evolution rate for granular α-Fe2O3 films was compared with the previously reported results for α-Fe2O3 powders [106,107] and TiO2 catalysts [108] and was found to be higher than both. The enhancement is due to the porous nature of the films, which increases the specific surface area. Cha et al. [109] prepared α-Fe2O3 nanorod thin films by metal organic chemical vapor deposition on Si substrates and studied the photocatalytic activity by RhB degradation. In the presence of α-Fe2O3 thin films, 99% of the RhB was found to degrade in 6h. Thin films of α-Fe2O3 nanotubes have been prepared on Fe foils by a two-step electrochemical anodization method by Zhang et al. [110]. The authors observed a higher photocatalytic activity for degradation of organic dyes than that of the nanoparticles and nanoporous thin films. Similar photocatalytic property enhancement was also observed by Qurashi et al. [111] for nano-ellipsoid α-Fe2O3 thin films for methyl orange degradation due to the enhancement in surface area and crystallinity. Basnet et al. [112] prepared α-Fe2O3 thin films and nanorods by electron beam evaporation by normal and oblique angle deposition (OAD) methods and reported a variation in photocatalytic activity with respect to change in morphology. The normal procedure was used to produce arrays of closely packed thin film structures, whereas the OAD technique was used to form well-aligned nanorods. Under visible light illumination, the thin film samples were more efficient at photocatalytically degrading MB, while the nanorod arrays were more efficient at inactivating Escherichia coli O157:H7. The size of the targeted agent and the different film morphologies result in different reactant/surface interactions, which is the main factor that determines photoactivity for dye degradation and bacterial disinfection. The photocatalytic degradation pathways of both MB and E. coli O157:H7 follow an oxidation process. The size of MB and E. coli O157:H7 are ∼1nm and ∼1μm, respectively. As a result, MB molecules are capable of reaching all the exposed surfaces of the plate-like structures of the thin films as well as the nanorods of the OAD films. In contrast, the E. coli O157:H7 is confined to the top surfaces of each film due to its larger structure, which decreases the effective contact of the bacteria on a α-Fe2O3 surface. The rate of adsorption of E. coli on a photocatalyst surface is positively correlated with its bactericidal effect [113]. Although α-Fe2O3 thin films show better photocatalytic activity in nanostructure form, problems are still encountered when forming composites with other materials. As such, different materials are being tried as dopants in α-Fe2O3, namely, Si [114–117], Ti [118–121], Ni [122], Pt [124–126], Al [116], Sn [127], Mg [128], N [129], and GO [95]. Si doping results in formation of Si4+ in the α-Fe2O3 films, which acts as an electron donor. Increases in donor concentration decrease the space charge region, which is essential for charge separation. However, doping with Si decreases the grain size, which increases the specific surface area and number of active sites for the photocatalytic reaction. A lot of factors affect the performance of Si-doped α-Fe2O3 electrodes such as incorporation of silicon into the hematite structure from lattice defects along with a nanostructure of small agglomerate/cluster enhancing hole transportation to the surface, all these factors contribute to the improvement in photocatalytic behavior [114]. Ni/α-Fe2O3 films were prepared by electrodeposition, and the effect of doping concentration on photocatalytic activity was studied. Ni atoms act as an ionized donor, which increases the charge carrier density, conductivity, and mobility, and 8mol% Ni in α-Fe2O3 showed the best PEC performance. P-type α-Fe2O3 films were prepared on n-Fe2O3 by Lin et al. [128] by atomic layer deposition to improve the photocatalytic water splitting. Uchiyama et al. [130] analyzed the effect of Sn dopant level on the photocurrent conversion efficiency of α-Fe2O3 films prepared by a dip coating method. The doping concentration was varied from 0 to 1mol% and the highest photocurrent efficiency was observed for the film with 0.1mol% Sn, which decreases with increasing Sn concentration up to 0.25mol%. The film with Sn mol%>0.5 showed a rutile phase and very low conversion efficiency. Sn-doped α-Fe2O3 nanocorals and nanowires were prepared by Ling et al. [127] using a hydrothermal method on FTO substrates in order to analyze PEC water splitting. The photocurrent density obtained for the nanocorals was 1.84mA/cm2, which is ∼1.5 times higher than that of the nanowires (1.24mA/cm2). Higher values of the photoactivity were due to the higher surface area. Enhanced photoactivity in Sn-doped hematite nanostructures should be due to the improved electrical conductivity and increased surface area. Meng et al. [131] theoretically explained the reason behind the enhancement in photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 by doping with Sn. Due to Sn doping, the band gap shrinks and the effective mass of the electron decreases, thereby improving the electron conductivity. Further, heavier doping with Sn results in the formation of an extra energy level between the VB and Fermi level and enhances the PEC performance. Ti-doped α-Fe2O3 thin films were prepared by Zandi et al. [132] using the atomic layer deposition method to enhance the PEC performance. The incorporation of Ti into the α-Fe2O3 electrodes enhances the water oxidation performance, and the thinner layers show better water oxidation performance. Incorporation of Ti enhances the number of holes and mobility of holes, which increases the lifetime of the holes and enhances water oxidation. Similar results were also reported by Miao et al. [120] for Ti-doped α-Fe2O3 electrodes in which the authors have increased the Ti-doping level in the α-Fe2O3 film by a solid-state reaction method and observed an enhancement in photoelectrochemical behavior with an increase in dopant concentration. As a consequence, the photo current density increases from 0.15 to 1.2mA/cm2. The enhancement in the current density is due to the change in surface morphology of the film nanostructures (Fig. 7 ). A similar effect was also reported by Glasscock et al. [133] for Ti-doped α-Fe2O3 films as a result of the decrease in the recombination effect of electrons and holes. Another attempt has been made by Zhang et al. [134] to prepare oriented Ti/α-Fe2O3 thin films by atmospheric pressure chemical vapor deposition (APCVD) for enhancing the photocatalytic performance. The films were polycrystalline with crystallite sizes of 20–50nm, having the preferred orientation along the (110) direction. A maximum efficiency was observed at ∼0.8at% Ti in hematite. The highest conversion efficiency was obtained to be 27.2%. Lian et al. also prepared Ti/α-Fe2O3 films by a sol gel method followed by annealing. The PEC performance increased due to Ti-doping as a result of the increase in conductivity of the films and the corresponding decreasing hole-electron recombination rate. Rioult et al. [135] have prepared epitaxial Fe2O3 and Ti/Fe2O3 films by Oxygen assisted molecular beam epitaxy to study the effect of layer thickness as well as Ti concentration on the Pt (111) substrate. The Ti doped films show higher IPCE values than that of the undoped Fe2O3 films. The improvement in the IPCE values is due to the lowering of diffusion length and decrease in recombination effect. Kumari et al. [136] prepared Zn-doped and Zn dot-doped α-Fe2O3 films by spray pyrolysis. In comparison to the Zn-doped films, the Zn-dotted films showed better photoelectrochemical performance. Further, Zn-dotted films with a Zn dot size of 23nm showed the highest photo current value. Similar effects were also observed by Iandolo et al. [137] for Au functionalized α-Fe2O3 films. Lower crystallite sizes of α-Fe2O3 and Au enhanced the photochemical performance of the Au/α-Fe2O3 films. Similar experiments were also carried out by Wang et al. [138], in which Au nanorods were prepared on α-Fe2O3 thin films and showed an enhancement in photocurrent due to an increase in light absorption. Kleiman-Shwarsctein et al. [139] prepared Al-doped α-Fe2O3 films for improving the PEC performance of the α-Fe2O3 electrode. Although most of the doping in semiconductors involves nonisovalent-doping leading to an enhancement in conductivity and shows better PEC performance, these authors tried to enhance the PEC characteristics by doping α-Fe2O3 with isovalent metals. The Al/α-Fe2O3 electrodes also showed improved PEC characteristics due to the incorporation of strain in the lattice. The incident photon to photocurrent efficiency (IPCE) value for 0.45at% Al/α-Fe2O3 is increased by 2–3 fold in comparison to the undoped electrodes. Gurudayal et al. [140] have prepared Mn doped α-Fe2O3 nanorods on FTO substrate by hydrothermal method, in order to improve the efficiency of the water splitting. The films with 5mol% Mn shows 75% increase in the photocurrent density in comparison to the pure α-Fe2O3, as a result of the decrease in recombination effect. Mao et al. [125] deposited Pt/α-Fe2O3 vertically aligned nanorods on gold substrates by electrochemical co-deposition to study the effect of Pt-doping on water splitting ability. The Pt-doping level varied from 2 to 6mol%, and Pt exists in a Pt4+ state, substituting into the Fe3+ lattice and acting as an electron donor. The photocurrents of the samples containing Pt are much higher than that of the sample without Pt, which indicates that a much larger number of photoelectrons participated in the water splitting reaction. Second, the Pt-doping might increase the electric field across the space charge layer, resulting in higher charge separation efficiency and a large photocurrent density [141]. The Pt-doped α-Fe2O3 nanorod arrays show an improvement in solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency (∼5%) for PEC water splitting compared to undoped samples. The photo current generated by Pt/α-Fe2O3 increases with increasing Pt current up to a certain critical level, and beyond that it decreases because of the increase in donor concentration, which reduces the width of the space charge layer and the Pt itself acts as a scattering and recombination center. Apart from the doping level, the length of the nanorod also affects the value of the photocurrent, which is found to increase with increasing nanorod length. This is due to the uniform dispersion of Pt metal in longer nanorods. Beyond a length of 15μm, the nanorods collapse so the photo current again decreases. Pt doping was also done by other authors for improving the photocatalytic properties of α-Fe2O3 thin films. For example, Zhang et al. [142] prepared α-Fe2O3 films by DC magnetron sputtering, above which a 2-nm Pt layer was formed to study the effect of the sputtering conditions on the gas phase photocatalytic activity of α-Fe2O3 films for decomposition of methanol. The analysis shows that the films deposited at lower pressure show a higher photocatalytic effect as a result of the lower crystallite size leading to a higher surface area. Except for the photocatalytic efficiencies, the films show good stability and >90% decomposition even after 10 experiments. Kamada et al. [126] synthesized Pt-doped α-Fe2O3 films on Au substrates for controlling the enzymatic activity of horseradish peroxidase (HRP) by photoirradiation. The reaction rate depends on wavelength and intensity of the incident light, and intermittent light irradiation causes a clear photoswitching behavior. The resting HRP is transformed into an activated state as a result of oxidation with holes generated in the valence band of the irradiated oxide semiconductor. Subsequently, the activated HRP leads to the enzymatic conversion of organic substrates accompanied by two-electron reduction to regenerate the resting state. As the HRP is supported with a narrow band gap semiconductor (Pt-doped α-Fe2O3 thin film), which is prepared by means of photoelectroless deposition, gentle energy from visible light is sufficient to trigger the reaction cycle. A series of Ag/α-Fe2O3 core–shell structured catalysts were prepared by Chou et al. [143] using a homogeneous deposition precipitation method. Urea is added in the reaction process for uniform formation of ferric hydrite followed by calcination at 400°C to form porous α-Fe2O3 on the surface of the silver core. The oxidation activity toward degradation of 2-propanol is enhanced due to the ability of Ag cores to activate O2, which is donated by the α-Fe2O3. He et al. [144] reported a combination effect of different cationic species on the performance of the α-Fe2O3 photoanode prepared by ink jet printing followed by pyrolysis. When Si and Al are individually added to iron oxide at the levels studied, the photoelectrolysis activity decreased, whereas low levels of Ti addition enhanced the photocurrents. Synergistic effects were observed, i.e., enhanced photocurrents when multiple impurities were added to α-Fe2O3. Similar studies were also made by Jang et al. [145] with Ag-doped α-Fe2O3 and Sn-doped Ag- α-Fe2O3 composites. These authors analyzed the effect of different molar ratios of Ag-doped α-Fe2O3 on the photocurrent and the effect of Sn-doping with a composite electrode on photocurrent. It was reported that a 50–50% Ag and Fe atomic mixture led to the highest photocurrent and 2% Sn addition enhances the photocurrent further. Another attempt was made by Watanabe et al. [146] using the sol gel method to prepare Ag- and Au-doped α-Fe2O3 films to improve the photoanodic performance. The authors reported that, with weak white light, the photoanodic current is higher in comparison to the photocurrent obtained by exposure to strong light. Carbon modified thin films (CMT) of α-Fe2O3 were prepared by thermal oxidation of metal sheets by Shaban et al. [147] to improve the efficiency of α-Fe2O3 for PEC water splitting. The photocatalytic activity was evaluated by measuring the rate of water splitting. The carbon modified α-Fe2O3 shows higher photoconversion efficiency (6.5%) than that of the α-Fe2O3 (∼3.5%) (Fig. 8 ). The CMT α-Fe2O3 was prepared at different temperatures and an enhancement in photocurrent with increasing temperature up to 850°C was observed, beyond which the photocurrent decreases as a result of overheating. Kim et al. [148] prepared graphene–carbon nanotube composite modified α-Fe2O3 anodes for enhancing PEC water splitting efficiencies. The modification was done with the aim to provide a conducting scaffold for transfer of charge from α-Fe2O3 to the conducting substrate. The composite electrode shows a 530% increase in photocurrent over that of the bare α-Fe2O3. However, the electrode with α-Fe2O3/carbon nano tubes (CNT) and α-Fe2O3–graphene shows only 200% and 240% enhancement. The higher enhancement in the case of composite electrodes is due to the 3D network by 1D CNT and 2D graphene, which increases the contact area of α-Fe2O3 with the electrode as well as allows more space for charge transport (Fig. 9 ). Meng et al. [149] prepared α-Fe2O3 embedded reduced graphene sheets and analyzed the PEC performance. PEC measurement results show that coupling the hematite nanoparticles with the RGO greatly increases the photocurrent and reduces the charge recombination rate due to the transfer of electrons from α-Fe2O3 to RGO sheets (Fig. 10 ). Thin films of α-Fe2O3 have also found application in deactivation of microorganisms. Akhavan et al. [150] reported a thickness dependent photocatalytic activity for single α-Fe2O3 film as well as for TiO2/Fe2O3 thin films grown by thermal evaporation on glass substrates. Higher α-Fe2O3 film thickness shows higher bacterial deactivation, which is the result of higher photocatalytic activity, as also found by other authors. These authors also reported a TiO2 thickness dependence on the bacterial deactivation, and 10-nm thickness was the optimized thickness of TiO2 over α-Fe2O3 to obtain the highest bacterial deactivation rate (higher than that of pure α-Fe2O3 film). The better photocatalytic activity in the visible range of the TiO2/α-Fe2O3 compared to the single α-Fe2O3 nanocrystallites is the result of the formation of a heterojunction between TiO2 and α-Fe2O3, where interdiffusion occurs due to annealing, leading to the formation of Ti-OFe bonds, which, in turn, helps reduce electron and hole recombination. A similar attempt was made by Sivula et al. [151] for WO3 layers on α-Fe2O3 layers to enhance the anodic performance of the α-Fe2O3 films. The basic idea is to produce a large number of holes near the semiconductor electrolyte interface to enhance the oxidation of water. Similar attempts were also made by Sharma et al. [152] for Zn/α-Fe2O3 films modified by Fe/TiO2 films for improving the PEC performance for H2 generation. These authors have analyzed the effect of Fe-TiO2 layer thickness on H2 production. The amount H2 production was found to be enhanced relative to that of the Zn/α-Fe2O3 film electrode as a result of the enhanced charge carrier separation at the interfaces, reduction in resistance, and increase in light absorption due to double layers. Hou et al. [153] developed α-Fe2O3/graphene/BiV1−x Mo x O4 core/shell nanorods for improving the PEC water splitting performance (Fig. 11 ). The heterojunction array was prepared by deposition of α-Fe2O3 nanorods onto a Ti substrate by a hydrothermal method followed by deposition of a graphene interlayer by photocatalytic reduction and application of a BiV1−x Mo x O4 shell by spin coating. The photocurrent value obtained from the heterojunction was ∼1.97mA/cm2, and the enhanced PEC is due to the improved charge separation of holes and electrons at the interfaces and the improved light absorption ability because of the hetero junction. The graphene interlayer acts as a conducting medium, which enhances the separation of electrons and holes, leading to lower recombination rates. Further, it acts as a path for transport of electrons and holes between α-Fe2O3 and BiV1−x Mo x O4. Diab et al. [154] have prepared a surface modified α-Fe2O3/CoO films on ITO substrate by thermal decomposition method to study the effect of CoO for water oxidation approach. The α-Fe2O3/CoO modified film shows a photo current of 0.7mA/cm2 in comparison to the α-Fe2O3 (photocurrent is 0.25mA/cm2). 4 Conclusions and future proposals This paper summarizes the basic mechanism of the photocatalytic properties of oxide semiconductors. Among all the oxide semiconductors, α-Fe2O3 has the advantage of low band gap and using the visible light for its photocatalytic reactions. Also, its non-toxic nature makes it readily usable without significant safety concerns. Many attempts have been made to overcome the basic problems like short hole diffusion length and high recombination rate. Many authors have reported a good result regarding the degradation of organic dyes in water by using α-Fe2O3 powders and modified α-Fe2O3. Still the removal of the photocatalyst from the water is a main issue, which can be solved by the usage of thin films of α-Fe2O3 in wastewater treatment. Many attempts have been made to use thin films of α-Fe2O3 for water splitting applications also. However the theoretical conversion efficiency has not yet achieved. To overcome the anomalies and usage of Fe2O3 in industrial level for waste water treatment as well as H2 production needs more modifications and research. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis has been attracting much research interest because of its wide applications in renewable energy and environmental remediation. There are many materials that are found to show good photocatalytic activity in the presence of ultraviolet (UV) and visible light. However, the applications of these materials are limited to the UV portion of sunlight. α-Fe2O3 has an advantage over the other conventional materials like TiO2, ZnO, etc. in using solar energy for photocatalytic applications due to its lower band gap ∼2.2eV value. As a result of which Fe2O3 is capable of absorbing a large portion of the visible solar spectrum (absorbance edge ∼600nm). Also its good chemical stability in aqueous medium, low cost, abundance and nontoxic nature makes it a promising material for photocatalytic water treatment and water splitting applications. Except these advantages the usage of Fe2O3 has been restricted by many anomalies such as higher e–h recombination effect, low diffusion length and VB positioning (VB is positive with respect to H+/H2 potential). This article reviews the research that has been carried out to overcome these basic limitations and to enhance the photocatalytic activity of α-Fe2O3.
coredata.dc:title: α-Fe2O3 as a photocatalytic material: A review
